Box 69315516, Ilam, Iran ⁎ Corresponding authors. Metal sulfide is a vital species of compound semiconductor materials, whose metallic ions are in mono-, bi-, or maybe in multi-form. Considering such materials, layered transition metal sulfide (LTMS) including layered transition metal dichalcogenides (LTMDs) like VS2 and VS4 (also called patronite mineral) has attracted growing interest. Moreover, it can be regarded as graphene analogs due to its large interlayer spacing and high theoretical specific capacity, enabling such materials to be applied in different fields i.e. photoelectric staffs, electro-catalysis phenomena, Li-containing batteries, and energy storage usages. Herein, a practical synthetic protocol is designated to construct mesoporous vanadium sulfides (VS2 and VS4) with controlled morphologies from VS2 (Flower-like), VS4 (Urchin-like), VS4 (Microsphere), and VS2 (Nanosheet assemblies) via adjusting the molar ratio of vanadium acetylacetonate and L-cysteine using a one-step solvothermal method. The catalytic activity of vanadium sulfides as an environmental catalyst has been considered for cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and 2-(phenoxymethyl)oxirane), oxidation of dibenzyl sulfide, and 1-phenylethan-1-ol. The prepared mesoporous vanadium sulfides have a higher surface area than the previously reported ones. The results and analysis revealed that the catalytic behavior of vanadium sulfides significantly depends on physical features such as morphology and specific surface area. The structure of the prepared materials was studied using a variety of characterization techniques: FTIR, XRD, TGA, BET, FE-SEM, EDX, and X-ray mapping Graphical Abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords VS2 (Flower-like) VS4 (Urchin-like) VS4 (Microsphere) VS2 (Nanosheet assemblies) Vanadium acetylacetonate L-cysteine Solvothermal method Cycloaddition 2-(phenoxymethyl)oxirane) Oxidation reactions Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction Mesoporous materials with non-silica structures have shown unique applications in a wide variety of scientific fields such as catalysis process and energy conversion and storage. Recently, a wide variety of research projects has been directed to the preparation of transition-metal mesoporous [1,2]. In this sense, metal sulfides have attracted great attention due to their excellent properties needed in different sciences such as sensors [1], separations [2], catalysis purposes [3], solar cells [4,5], fuel cells [5], and batteries [6]. In particular, vanadium sulfides are made of variable molar ratios of sulfur and vanadium elements and appear in different molecular formulas such as VS2, VS4, V2S5, V2S3, VS, V3S, and VS6 [7–17]. Regarding these vanadium sulfide structures, VS2 and VS4 have attracted much attention in the past few years [18]. It is worth mentioning that vanadium disulfide (VS2) is a typical member of the family of dichalcogenides (a class of materials consisting of one metal atom, which is sandwiched between two chalcogen atoms), [18]. Sulfur-containing transition metal dichalcogenides such as VS2 and WS2 exhibit layered structures with unique properties; including, physical, chemical, optical, magnetic, and electrical properties, which make them attractive to be applied in different fields such as electrocatalysis, batteries, photoelectric staffs, and energy storage usage [19]. Furthermore, the VS4 crystal has a chain-like structure, where the V4 + ions coordinated to sulfur dimers (Scheme 1 ), [18].The individual VS4 chains have interacted with weak van der Waals forces which in VS4 interchain distance is about 0.583 [17]. As a layer transition metal sulfide, VS2 crystal, which is hexagonally packed between two trigonal atomic layers of S atoms, has a layered structure with the interlayer distance of 5.76 Å (Scheme 1), [18]. It should be noted that the oxidation state of the vanadium in VS2 is the same as that of VS4; but, intriguingly, the structure of sulfides is quite different (S2− existed in VS2 and S2 2− existed in VS4). Accordingly, several synthetic procedures have been introduced to produce vanadium sulfides including “top-down” (such as exfoliation) and “bottom-up” (such as solvothermal and hydrothermal preparation) methodes, [18]. Hydrothermal and/or solvothermal methods with liquid-phase medium are effective methods to produce materials with improved physical and chemical properties which can be applied in both industrial and biomedical areas. Generally, the reaction medium of hydrothermal synthesis is water, while the solvothermal method is generally taking place in an organic liquid. The high consumption of fossil fuels has resulted in fastly rising degrees of anthropogenic CO2 emission, causing severe environmental issues over the past decades [20–22]. Significant research efforts in the field of sustainable catalysis have aimed at utilizing CO2 to create valuable products, i.e. urethane compounds [23], formic acid [24] and carbonates [25]. The production process of the mentioned compounds can be carried out in presence of an acid catalyst (e.g. a metal ion or a proton) which results in activating epoxides for the nucleophilic attack [26]. In this context, various kinds of homogeneous or heterogeneous catalysts have already been efficiently used to prepare cyclic carbonates. It is worth mentioning that heterogeneous catalysts have been regarded as the best choice due to their easier isolation and recyclability as compared to homogeneous ones [27–32]. Sulfoxides are found in many bioactive compounds considered as versatile functional groups in organic chemistry [33]. Traditional methods used in preparing sulfoxides are performed while oxidating the related sulfides using a variety of oxidants and catalysts [34]. Although all of these methods are beneficial, some of them have one or more of the following drawbacks: use of toxic oxidants, limitation in functional group compatibility, overoxidation to sulfones and separation problems from the reaction medium [35]. To solve these drawbacks, the use of nanocatalysts can be very beneficial – especially when the active sites of heterogeneous catalysts increase [36]. Moreover, oxidation of hydroxyl group in alcohols is one of the most important reactions in organic chemistry, since it converts the readily available alcohols into valuable carbonyl compounds that deserve further functionalization [37–39]. Accordingly, several methodologies have been developed over the years to carry out such reactions. Furthermore, a large number of traditional oxidants is based on CrO3 [40] or hypervalent iodine [41], which are usually used in stoichiometric quantities having some specific disadvantages such as generation of toxic and hazardous wastes, arduous separation, and difficulty in recycling of catalysts [42]. The design and use of green catalysts and catalytic systems have become an important issue in chemical research. In this sense, the use of nanomaterials in combination with a readily-available and waste-free terminal oxidant (such as H2O2 or O2) is a clean choice [43]. More generally, the preparation of porous, especially mesoporous metal sulfides, are a big challenge in material chemistry. Herein, a versatile synthetic protocol is reported to synthesize mesoporous vanadium sulfides (VS2 and VS4) with high surface area and controlled morphologies (VS2 (Flower-like), VS4 (Urchin-like), VS4 (Microsphere), and VS2 (Nanosheet assemblies) synthesized via adjusting the molar ratio of vanadium acetylacetonate and L-cysteine using the one-step solvothermal method (Scheme 2 ). The versatility and catalytic ability of the obtained mesoporous materials were tested for the chemical conversion of the CO2 cycloaddition with 2-(phenoxymethyl)oxirane), oxidation of dibenzyl sulfide, and 1-phenylethan-1-ol. Our experimental studies indicate that the VS2 (Nanosheet assemblies) shows higher activity than the other three structures, which is due to the large surface area and abundant channels to facilitate the mass transfer [42]. Experimental General procedure for the synthesis of vanadium sulfide Vanadium sulfides were synthesized applying a one-step solvothermal method. Regarding this synthesis, appropriate amounts of L-cysteine and vanadium acetylacetonate were dissolved in water (5 mL) and dimethylformamide (15 mL), respectively. These solutions were mixed and sonicated for 30 min. After sonicating, the mixture was transferred to an autoclave and, then, heated for 24 h at 160°C. In the final step, the mixture was centrifuged, washed with ethyl acetate towice and, then, dried at 60°C in a vacuum. Cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with 2-(phenoxymethyl)oxirane The catalytic chemical conversion of CO2 was done through stirring a mixture of 2-(phenoxymethyl)oxirane (17 mmol) and catalyst (0.5 mol%) in a 5 mL glass tube with 2 mL of DMF. The reaction bottle then pressurized with 1.2 MPa of CO2 at room temperature. Moreover, the reaction mixture was heated to 70 ˚C. After finishing the reaction, the mixture was cooled down to room temperature. Afterwards, the mixture was centrifuged to separate vanadium sulfide and, then, washed with ethyl acetate. Furthermore, the product was isolated and purified using column chromatography. The oxidation of dibenzyl sulfide To a mixture of dibenzyl sulfide (1 mmol) and vanadium sulfides (2 mol%) in ethyl acetate (2 mL), 30% aqueous H2O2 (0.3 mL) was added. After reaction completion, the catalyst was separated using centrifugation and, then, washed with ethyl acetate towice. Subsequently, the product was extracted (in ethyl acetate). Finally, the organic layer was evaporated to afford dibenzyl sulfoxide. The oxidation of (1-phenylethan-1-ol) To a mixture of (1-phenylethan-1-ol) (1 mmol) and vanadium sulfide (2 mol%) in CH3CN (2 mL), 30% H2O2 (0.3 mL) was slowly dropped in. The reaction mixture was stirred for 60 min. After completion of the reaction, the desired catalyst was removed via centrifugation and, then, washed using ethyl acetate. It is worth mentioning that the product was then extracted using ethyl acetate (20 mL). Finally, the organic layer evaporated to afford acetophenone. Results and discussion Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of VS2 (Flower-like), VS4 (Urchin-like), VS4 (Microsphere), and VS2 (Nanosheet assemblies) are shown in Fig. 1 a-d. The XRD pattern of VS2 (Flower-like) compound, synthesized through mixing the active materials (L-cysteine and vanadium acetylacetonate with the molar ratio of 1.5:1), displays main peaks at 2θ = 34.5°, 47°, and 57.5° which can be well-indexed to (101), (102), and (110) planes of VS2, respectively (Fig. 1a), [43]. The XRD pattern of VS4 (Urchin-like) compound, prepared via mixing L-cysteine and vanadium with the molar ratio of 5:1, shows main peaks at 2θ =13.7°, 27°, 30.0°, 36.4°, 47.5°, and 60° corresponding to crystal planes of (0 1 1), (2 1 1), (4 0 0), (-4 0 2), (-4 2 2), and (3 4 1) of monoclinic VS4 (Fig. 1b), [44]. The XRD pattern of VS4 (Microsphere) compound synthesized via mixing L-cysteine and vanadium acetylacetonate with the molar ratio of 1:3 shows main peaks at 2θ range of 7-70°. Moreover, the XRD patterns evidently show that the shifting of (2 1 1), (-4 0 2), and (3 4 1) peaks from 2θ =27°, 36°, 47.5° are well indexed to monoclinic VS4 (Fig. 1c), [44]. Finally, The XRD pattern of VS2 (Nanosheet assemblies) prepared by the combination of L-cysteine and vanadium acetylacetonate with the molar ratio of 1:5 exhibits main peaks at 2θ = 34.5°, 47°, and 57.5° which can be well-indexed to (101), (102), and (103) planes of VS2, respectively (Fig. 1d), [45]. The FTIR spectra of the prepared materials in the wavenumber range of 400-4000 cm−1 are shown in Fig. 2 . Moreover, the four FTIR spectra of vanadium sulfides displayed similar characteristic peaks. Specifically, the peaks located at 549 and 992 cm−1 correspond to the vibrational stretching of (V-S-V) and the (V=S) bonds, respectively [45]. X-ray mapping and EDX analysis were used to identify the elemental construction of materials. These analyses indicate the presence of V and S elements in all structures (Fig. 3 ). These results are also in agreement with the X-ray mapping images shown in Fig. 3. Furthermore, these images confirm that V and S are homogeneously dispersed (Figs. 4–7 ). The effect of various vanadium acetylacetonate and L-cysteine molar ratios on the morphology and structure of the resulting vanadium sulfides was investigated applying SEM, as shown in Figs. 8-11 . As illustrated in Fig. 8, the synthesized material via mixing of L-cysteine and vanadium with the molar ratio of 1.5:1 is composed of uniform VS2 in a Flower-like structure. In this sense, while increasing the molar ratio of L-cysteine to 5, the morphology of the product changed to VS4 with an Urchin-like structure (Fig. 9 ). Further increasing the molar ratio of vanadium acetylacetonatev to 3 and 5 leads to form VS4 with Microsphere and VS2 with Nanosheet assemblies structures, respectively (Figs. 10 and 11 ). Therefore, it can be concluded that the molar ratio of L-cysteine and vanadium affects both the composition and the morphology of the corresponding vanadium sulfides. A comparative thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curves of VS2 (Flower-like), VS4 (Urchin-like), VS4 (Microsphere), and VS2 (Nanosheet assemblies) materials are shown in Fig. 12 . The TG curve of VS2 (Flower-like) shows two-step weight losses in its TGA analysis (Fig. 12a). The first stage, with a low percentage of weight loss (3 %) at T< 200°C, is the result of removing the physically absorbed organic solvents and water. Additionally, the second stage (from 210°C to nearly 530°C) can be attributed to the loss of sulfur molecules resulted from the decomposition of VS2 (Flower-like). Notably, the approximate amount of sulfur molecules was found to be about 17% of the total solid composite. The thermoanalytical graph of VS4 (Urchin-like) is demonstrated in Fig. 12b. The TGA result shows that the weight loss of the material occurs in three steps, in which the total mass loss (from 25 to 500°C) is about 14%. The first stage (25–200°C), with a mass loss of 7%, is due to the removal of adsorbed water and other solvents. This thermal behavior indicates that this material is greatly moisture adsorbent. The second and third stages of the mass losses (7%), occurred at 210-500°C, are related to the decomposition of sulfur of the Urchin-like structure. Fig. 12c shows the thermoanalytical graph of VS2 (Nanosheet assemblies). This TGA diagram shows that the weight loss happened in three steps and the overall mass loss is about 24%. The first step at 25-200°C, with 14% mass loss, is related to the commission of adsorbed water and organic solvents. The second and third stages of the mass losses (6 and 4%) occurred at between 210-440 and 450-540°C, corresponding to the stepwise decomposition of vanadium sulfide. Finally, the thermal stability and behavior of the VS4 (Microsphere) were studied using TGA (Fig. 12d), too. Initial decomposition for the VS4 (Microsphere) starts at around 25-200°C with a mass loss of 14%, which can be attributed to the evaporation of water and other solvents. At 210-540°C, mass loss of about 18% was observed that can be attributed to the loss of sulfur molecules through the decomposition of VS4 (Microsphere). N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the prepared vanadium sulfides are measured, the related isotherm of which is shown in Fig. 13 . Moreover, the calculated specific pore volumes, surface areas, and pore diameters are summarized in Table 1 . The corresponding isotherm in Fig. 13 demonstrates that all structures possess an evident hysteresis loop of type IV in N2 adsorption-desorption. As evident from our comparison, it is easy to find out that the surface area and pore volume of the corresponding metal sulfide improves while increasing the molar ratio of vanadium acetylacetonate to 5 in the related synthesized procedure. Catalytic studies To examine the catalytic properties of vanadium sulfides, three different reactions were studied: (i) the CO2 cycloaddition with 2-(phenoxymethyl)oxirane),(ii) oxidation of dibenzyl sulfide and,(iii) oxidation of 1-phenylethan-1-ol. Initially, the catalytic activity of VS2 (Nanosheet assemblies) was evaluated for the CO2 cycloaddition of 2-(phenoxymethyl) oxirane (the related results of which are summarized in Table 2 ). The reaction parameters including the reaction temperature, solvent, and amount of catalyst were screened for this cycloaddition reaction. Primarily, several solvents were screened and it was observed that the desired product was not obtained in toluene and THF (Table 2). However, the reaction was highly effective in DMF. When the reaction was conducted at room temperature, the yield was very low (Table 2). Accordingly, 70 ˚C was selected as the ideal temperature for this reaction. Furthermore, the progress of the reaction depended on the amount of VS2 (Nanosheet assemblies). Notably, the reaction was effective in presence of 0.5 mol% of VS2 (Nanosheet assemblies) catalyst. Afterwards, the catalytic performance of vanadium sulfides was checked for the CO2 cycloaddition with 2-(phenoxymethyl)oxirane) under the optimal reaction conditions, as listed in Table 3 . It can be concluded that VS2 (Nanosheet assemblies) showed more activity for CO2 conversion than the other vanadium sulfides due to its high porosity and surface area. The mechanism of the desired reaction of CO2 and 2-(phenoxymethyl)oxirane) is proposed as shown in Scheme 3 . The catalytic activity of vanadium sulfide samples was also evaluated for the oxidation of dibenzyl sulfide to dibenzyl sulfoxide. In this sense, the study was initiated with VS2 (Nanosheet assemblies) as the catalyst for the conversion of dibenzyl sulfide to dibenzyl sulfoxide in presence of hydrogen peroxide under solvent-free conditions. Herein, the conversions to dibenzyl sulfoxide 35% was reached (Table 4 , entry 1). Interestingly, higher yields of dibenzyl sulfoxide were obtained by switching the solvent to ethanol or ethyl acetate. To improve the conversion, the effect of the catalyst amount was examined on the yield of dibenzyl sulfoxide. It was observed that 2 mol% of the catalyst was the optimum value for this conversion. After optimization of this oxidation reaction, the catalytic activity of other vanadium sulfides with different morphology for the oxidation of dibenzyl sulfide was studied to compare their effective catalytic properties. Surprisingly, VS2 (Nanosheet assemblies) exhibited significantly higher activity than other vanadium sulfides, as summarized in Table 5 . Under the optimized condition, a study on the substrate scope was carried out, the representative results of which are summarized in Table 6 . A suggested mechanism for the oxidation of dibenzyl sulfide has been outlined in Scheme 4 . Oxidation of 1-phenylethan-1-ol to acetophenone was the final reaction, carried out to study the catalytic properties of the synthesized vanadium sulfides. This reaction was performed in presence of hydrogen peroxide as a green oxidant. Initially, oxidation reactions of 1-phenylethan-1-ol to acetophenone were carried out using H2O2 under different reaction conditions in presence of VS2 (Nanosheet assemblies). Experimental results show that in the absence of the catalyst no conversion of alcohol was obtained (Table 7 , entry 6). Optimization studies of the solvent effect in this reaction revealed that CH3CN is the best solvent for this catalytic system. Control experiments showed that increasing the amount of catalyst resulted in the formation of acetophenone in 92% yield. After optimization of the oxidation reaction and comparing the tested vanadium sulfides, it was revealed that VS2 (Nanosheet assemblies) exhibited higher catalytic activity than the other vanadium sulfide samples (Table 8 ). The mechanism of this reaction is proposed, as shown in Scheme 5 . Reusability of the catalyst One of the important aspects of a catalytic process is its reusability. In this sense, the reusability of the VS4 (Microsphere) for the oxidative conversion of dibenzyl sulfide to dibenzyl sulfoxide was considered under optimal reaction conditions. The catalyst was easily isolated from the reaction, washed twice with ethyl acetate and, then, dried and reused for the subsequent run. This catalyst was recycled and reused four times without a notable decrease in its activity (Fig. 14 ). In order to show the structural stability of the catalyst after recycling, the recovered catalyst was characterized using FT-IR and TGA analyses. The FT-IR and TGA techniques of the recovered VS4(Microsphere) indicate that this catalyst can be recycled without any change in its structure(Figs. 15-16 ). In order to show the efficiency of VS2 (Nanosheet assemblies) in the described rection, the obtained results for the oxidation of dibenzyl sulfide were compared with the previously reported methods in the literature (Table 9 ). Evidently, this catalyst shows better results in terms of the reaction time and yield. Conclusions In summary, mesoporous vanadium sulfides with high surface area and controlled morphologies; including, VS2 (Flower-like), VS4 (Urchin-like), VS4 (Microsphere), and VS2 (Nanosheet assemblies) were successfully prepared via adjusting the molar ratio of vanadium acetylacetonate and L-cysteine applying a one-step solvothermal method. In addition, the influence of morphologies, surface area, and pore size on their catalytic performance was exactly considered in this research project. In this sense, VS2 (Nanosheet assemblies) demonstrates the exhibited high catalytic activity in the corresponding reactions due to its structure that provides a large surface area and abundant channels to facilitate the mass transfer. We believe that this scientific appraisal about the catalytic performance and structural properties of different morphologies of vanadium sulfides will improve present knowledge on the rational design, synthesis, properties, and applications of metal sulfides. coredata.dc:description: Metal sulfide is a vital species of compound semiconductor materials, whose metallic ions are in mono-, bi-, or maybe in multi-form. Considering such materials, layered transition metal sulfide (LTMS) including layered transition metal dichalcogenides (LTMDs) like VS2 and VS4 (also called patronite mineral) has attracted growing interest. Moreover, it can be regarded as graphene analogs due to its large interlayer spacing and high theoretical specific capacity, enabling such materials to be applied in different fields i.e. photoelectric staffs, electro-catalysis phenomena, Li-containing batteries, and energy storage usages. Herein, a practical synthetic protocol is designated to construct mesoporous vanadium sulfides (VS2 and VS4) with controlled morphologies from VS2 (Flower-like), VS4 (Urchin-like), VS4 (Microsphere), and VS2 (Nanosheet assemblies) via adjusting the molar ratio of vanadium acetylacetonate and L-cysteine using a one-step solvothermal method. The catalytic activity of vanadium sulfides as an environmental catalyst has been considered for cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and 2-(phenoxymethyl)oxirane), oxidation of dibenzyl sulfide, and 1-phenylethan-1-ol. The prepared mesoporous vanadium sulfides have a higher surface area than the previously reported ones. The results and analysis revealed that the catalytic behavior of vanadium sulfides significantly depends on physical features such as morphology and specific surface area. The structure of the prepared materials was studied using a variety of characterization techniques: FTIR, XRD, TGA, BET, FE-SEM, EDX, and X-ray mapping
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis and characterization of mesoporous vanadium sulfides as environmental catalysts for the cycloaddition of CO2 with 2-(phenoxymethyl)oxirane) and oxidation reactions
